sp.p: Faidth, and you have viry proper notions about wives. So, whin the dare crater gave a marriage hint, why, I told her a dale of boister, consarning an old cross fadther, and being under age, and that I could not marry these three months. For, you know, one does not stand for a good double handful of oaths, and lies, whin one wants to ruin a sweet, kind, angel, that one loves.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!—Suppose you were to make a sham marriage.

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: A sham marriage?—Faidth, and I would make that, if there were not a parcel of low rascals, that make halters.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Pshaw! That's a paltry, mechanical, fear.

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: But, you—you were telling me, you know, of—a—scheme—

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Oh! The contract.

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: Ay, faidth! The contract. You said you would shew it me.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: I will—I have brought it for that purpose [feeling for his pocket-book]. I, lately, found it an efficacious expedient.

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: And succissful?

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Would have been, but for an unlucky accident.

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: But there is one small impidimint.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: What is that?

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: Westminster hall.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Baw! A house of cards.

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: Oh, and that it is; for 'tis supported by knaves, and full of tricks.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Here—here is the very contract I myself gave.

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: Ay! [endeavouring to conceal her eagerness.]

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: And here a counterfeit copy, with a few slight, but essential, alterations.

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: I understand—To put the change upon her. [with an anxious eye, continually, toward the contract.]

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Which you may easily take, or make, an opportunity to do.

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: [with affected indifference] Will, thin, lind them both to me; and, faidth, you shall see fine divarsion.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: No—I—I'll have them copied for you. This is signed, and sealed

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: Arrah, what of that?—Ha! ha! ha! Sure, you are not afraid you would be obliged to marry a man?

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: No—The only danger, in trusting them to you, is that of losing them. And, even then, there could be no ill consequence; except by falling into the hands of one who is far enough from London.

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: Ay, ay, lit me have them—I give you my honour to make a proper use of them.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! You are a promising youth, and it would be a pity such talents should be baulked—So, here—here.

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: Promising? Oh, faidth, and I hope to surprise even you, yoursilf. You shall prisently hear of the succiss of your schaimes.

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: [looking after Harriet] There a' goes—Hop, step, and jump!— (Pause)—Ecod, she does it featly!

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: She! What's that you say?

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: How a' skipp'd into the carriage!—There! Off it drives! Whur-r-r-r! Rattling away!

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: What does the fellow mean?—S'death!—Sure!—Who are you talking of?

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Why, of that Irish, gentleman-like, Lady.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Lady!

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: I wur coming straight to tell you—There is a plot, mun, against you!

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: A plot! [runs toward the door.]

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Nay, you are too late!—A's gone!—Three streets off by this.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Confusion!

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Ees—She means to breed a confusion.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Who?

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Miss Harriet.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Harriet!—By heavens 'tis she!—

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Ees—'tis she.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Secure fool! Ineffable ideot!—And, yet, in that disguise, Lucifer himself could not have discovered her!—And who told you?

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Why, his worship's gentleman, Mr. Lapelle—A' o'erheard her tell my Lord aw her plot.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: What course shall I take?

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Suppose I wur to watch, and, when she comes back, let your worship know?

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Do so—But be very careful—And be very secret.

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Ees, ees; I remember the place, mun.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Away—be watchful and be rewarded.

This is a thunder stroke!—Lord Morden in the plot, too!—It will come to Lady Morden's ears, I shall be blown, all my plans disconcerted, myself laughed at, and my reputation eternally ruined!— [walks about] Ha!—There is one way to prevent the mischief, yet—By heavens, it cannot fail!—I will go to Lady Morden, and, with feigned penitence, tell her every circumstance, myself; only making her believe I knew Harriet, when I returned the contract. She wist admire my candour, think my contrition real▪ and thus will I turn this seeming disaster to excellent account, by making it an additional proof of sincerity, and affection for her Ladyship!—Dear Wit, I thank thee; thou never forsakest me at a crisis!—Indeed!—My Lord! And my young Lady!—Ah, ha!—But you shall find one, perhaps, who can plot, as deeply as yourselves.

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: INTO what an abyss of evils have I plunged, through inexperience, want of reflection, and an absurd imitation of fashionable follies!—Lapelle.

sp.speaker: Lapelle.
sp.p: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: Is the young—young gentleman returned?

sp.speaker: Lapelle.
sp.p: [significantly] No, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: I am on the rack!—The liberties in which Lady Morden permits this Sir Frederic are insupportable!—Unable to be silent, and ashamed to complain, I am tortured, by contending passions.—Lapelle—Let me know the instant—the—the young gentleman comes back.

sp.speaker: Lapelle.
sp.p: [going] Yes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: Stay— [to himself] What if I were to inform Lady Morden of this affair?—Surely, she could not shut her eyes against such a palpable, such an unprincipled, attempt at seduction!— [aloud] Go, and tell your Lady, I beg to speak with her, a moment.

What an absurd being is man!—Not a fortnight ago, Lady Morden was totally indifferent to me; and, now I am in danger of losing her, I find I love her—To distraction love her!—Yet to sink into a civil, sober, domestic, man—To become the standing jest of all those highspirited companions whose society I have courted, whose maxims I have pretended to admire!—

div3.head: SCENE III. LORD MORDEN, LADY MORDEN.

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: So, my Lord, in melancholy contemplation; and at home, too!

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: Yes, madam.

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: Lud! I wonder how your Lordship can endure home! Of all places, in the world, home is, certainly, the most disagreeable.

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: Did not your Ladyship meet Lapelle?

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: Lapelle! no.

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: I—I wished to see your Ladyship.

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: To see me! What can your Lordship possibly want with me?

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: To speak to you.

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: Speak to me!—You perfectly surprise me.

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: On a subject which—I—I scarcely know how to begin.

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p:
Ha! ha! ha! What can have made your Lordship so serious? Ha! ha! ha!
I declare, I never saw you look so grave before!—This must be some very important secret, that can occasion your Lordship to look so very dismal!—I vow, I am quite impatient—Come, my Lord—Why don't you proceed?

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: I—I begin to find—I have been very foolish.

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! Is that the secret?

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: I—I feel I have been to blame.

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: To blame, my Lord! How? Which way?—Or, if you have, how does it concern me?

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: Your Ladyship used to think our interests inseparable.

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: For which your Lordship always laughed at me. And, I freely own, I was a very silly—out of the way woman.

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: Perhaps not, madam.

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: How, my Lord!—Not?—Your Lordship is very polite, but you know very well I was.

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: Lady Morden, you once loved me—You yourself, not long since, kindly owned you did.

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: Very true, my Lord; but why—why now should you reproach me with my follies?

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: I feel the severity of your reproof—It is no more than I merit!

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: [with affected surprise] I, really, don't understand your Lordship!—I—I meant no reproof—We loved each other as long as it was agreeable to us, and, if my passion happened to out-last your Lordship's, that was none of your fault. These are the principles of—of all rational people, you know, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: They are principles, madam, that, from my soul, I wish I had never heard!

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: Upon my honour, you astonish me!—Have not I learnt them from you, yourself?

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: Unjustifiable, madam, as my conduct may have been, I never carried them to the same excess as Sir Frederic Fashion.

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: [with an air of pique] Sir Frederic Fashion may, perhaps, be as capable of reformation as your Lordship.

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: Your Ladyship may—may be partial.

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: Partial!

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: Who so great a libertine as this Sir Frederic?

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: Has been—He has candour enough to confess it.

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: Has been!—Madam, there exists a present proof of deliberate seduction!—An injured Lady!—

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: [smiling] Oh! What the—the, the Croat.

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: Madam!

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: What's your surprise, my Lord? Don't I tell you he has confessed all his follies to me?

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: But, madam, did he mention the contract?

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: To be sure! And the—the counterfeit copy—With the generous manner in which he, just now, returned Harriet the origin; though she thought he did not know her.

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: I am petrified!—Lady Morden—I perceive, I have lost your affections.

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: My Lord—I am above dissimulation. Yes—I own I have a passion, too permanent to be shaken; and the satisfaction of a self-assurance that he who, at present, possesses my heart, will not, so soon, be weary of me, as he who had it before.

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: You cut me to the soul!—Did you know what I feel!

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: Feel, my Lord! Ha, ha, ha! Oh fie!—Your Lordship is a man of fashion, not of feeling.

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: Hovering mischief, madam, has quickened benumbed nature in me. [kneels and takes her hand] Oh! let me conjure you, Lady Morden, to reflect on your present situation! I have conducted you to the horrid precipice of guilt, and destruction! Oh suffer me to save, to snatch, you from danger!

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

div3.head: SCENE IV. LORD MORDEN, LADY MORDEN, SIR FREDERIC.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! How now, my Lord! Ha, ha, ha! Making love to your wife?

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! Oh! Sir Frederic, if you had but come a little sooner, you would have heard the most delightful morality!

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! Morality from my Lord?

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, morality from my Lord!

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! Nay, I assure you, he is quite serious. [retires coquetting with Sir Frederic.]

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: Rejected! Ridiculed! Despised! Their sport! Their scorn!—Their subject for open sarcasm, laughter, and contempt! Oh! Insupportable. [Lord Morden retires into his own room.]

div3.head: SCENE V. LADY MORDEN, SIR FREDERIC.

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! My Lord has a mind to fall in love with me, once more.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Nobody, but my Lord, madam, would ever have ceased, a moment, to love you!

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: Well, Sir Frederic, and may I, then, at last, flatter myself I have found that sympathy of soul, for which I so long have sighed?

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Alas, madam, I dare not rank myself your equal!—No, I dare not!—There is such infinitude of perfection in your every thought, look, and expression, that to merit you were to be, as you are, something celestial!—Yet, such virtue as mere humanity may arrive at, I will exhaust nature with endeavours, and weary heaven with prayers, to acquire!

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: There is, surely, some secret charm in your words.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p:
Did I think the gratification of any sinister passion influenced my present conduct; were it not my hope to remove you from the cold embrace of satiated apathy, to the swee and endless transports of love, founded on, permit me to say, on a congeniality of soul and senriment; did I not feel an innate conviction that there, already, subsists, between us, a tie of the most indissoluble nature, an immaculate tie, a
marriage of the mind, superior infinitely to all human institutions; did I not think, and feel, thus, I would, instantly, dreadful as the image is to thought, renounce that heaven which I have had the presumption to contemplate, nay aspire to possess!

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: And if, after all this, you should prove false, Sir Frederic!

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: False, madam!—Oh! Let me conjure you to inflict any punishment on me, rather than that of suspecting my sincerity!—Thus, kneeling, on this angelic hand, I vow—

div3.head: SCENE VI. LADY MORDEN, SIR FREDERIC, LORD MORDEN.

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: I cannot resist the impulse which—How!—Sir Frederic!

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: [rising] My Lord. [with perfect indifference.]

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: So, madam!

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: So, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: You can listen to morality from others, madam, if not from me!

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: Oh! I—I have no dislike to a sermon, when I—admire the preacher.

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: Madam—If you have no respect for my honour, you might have some for my feelings, and—

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: [interrupting him] A, a—Hold, hold, my Lord—You are beginning your discourse again; but I am in a hurry, and will hear you draw your conclusions some other opportunity.

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: Madam—

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: Nay, I will, upon my honour.

div3.head: SCENE VII. LORD MORDEN, SIR FREDERIC.

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: Hold, Sir; a word with you, if you please.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: With me, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: With you.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Willingly. Your Lordship seems in so pleasant a humour—

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: Sir, I am in a humour neither to be trifled with nor sneered at.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! I can assure your, Ha, ha, ha! your Lordship, no man is happier to see you in your present temper than I am.

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: Look you, Sir Frederic, you and I have been too long of the same school for me to be ignorant of your principles. But I begin to detest them!

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: They are now, at this very moment, rending my heart. They have planted a nest of adders in my bosom.—In short, Sir—You must forbear your visits to Lady Morden.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: My Lord—

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: I am serious—determined.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! When her Ladyship gives me this advice, it may—perhaps—be followed.

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: It must and shall be followed, Sir, when I give it.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: Ridiculous as it may appear, to you, and such as you, I feel, and will assert, a husband's rights.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p:
Ha, ha, ha! I congratulate your
Lordship, on the keenness, and delicacy, of your feelings; they give me great pleasure; infinite pleasure, upon my soul. Ha, ha, ha!—As to—a husband's rights, I—have no doubt, you will—very shortly—be in full possession of them all.

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: Sir, I will have you know, I am, at present, in full possession of them all.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: May be so, egad!

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: And can no longer forbear telling you, I believe you to be a villain.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Ah, now, your Lordship is perfectly explicit. [draw and fight.]

div3.head: SCENE VIII. LORD MORDEN, SIR FREDERIC, GABRIEL, who runs fearless between them, and looks first at one, then at the other.

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: How now, sirrah! How dare you take this liberty?

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Nay, ecod, there do seem to be some danger in it; an I had not dared to dare, but that I thought that your Lordship wou'd na stick I.

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: Be gone, sirrah!

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Nay, but my Lady sent me, and would be glad to speak wi' your honour's worship.

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: With me?

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Oh no! Not wi' your Lordship's honour's worship; but wi' his worship's honour, Sir Frederic Fashion.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: This is no place, my Lord: we'll settle this business to-morrow—To-morrow, my Lord—To-morrow—

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: Damnation!—Torture!—To-morrow?—He has some concealed meaning—A thousand little circumstances tell me, some mischief is brooding—I could not have believed Lady Morden so confirmed, so far gone, in guilt.—The behaviour of them all, their dark allusions, their sarcasms, pointed at me, convince me, they are acting in conjunction, to hold me up—How now, sirrah! What do you stand gaping at?—How durst you come between us?

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Why, ecod, I knew that, wi' us, i'th country, murder would have been against the commandements; and I had forgot that, here, in town, you have no commandements.

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: This fool can see the excesses of passion in their true light.

sp.speaker: Gabriel
sp.p: I'm sorry 'at I angered your Lordship's worship; becase as why, I wur determined to do like the rest of my neighbours; for, sartinly, wur a body to keep the commandements, while every body else is breaking them—a'd be a poor devil, indeed. [Lord Morden walks about] Belike, your Lordship be a bit jealousy, like?

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: How, sirrah!

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Nay, I should no' a' wondered an you wur—An I had no' been told that your Londoneers be never jealousy, like.

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: Should not have wondered!—Why not, sirrah?

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Nay, ecod, I munna tell!

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: Tell what?

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Nay, that's it—As I said, I munna tell!

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: [puts his hand to his sword] Speak all you know, instantly, or—

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: [with half serious half sulky reproof] Nay, nay, donna be in a passion, your worship—I be no goose, you munna spit me.

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: Speak, I say—I'll have your secret, or your soul.

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Ecod, I believe, your worship will be puzzled to find either—Tho' that Sir Frederic be an old fox—A's used to steal chicken.

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: Be explicit; what has he done?

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Done—Oh!—A's—

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Promised me a place!

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: Zounds!

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: And, moreover, a' ga' me a purse; which is better still: for, your worship's grace do know that, an egg, in hand, is better nur a hen, in expectation.

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: Suppose, sirrah, I give you my purse, too.

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Nay, ecod, an you gi' it me—I b'lieve, I shall—I shall take it.

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: There, Sir.

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Thank your worship's Lordship.— [Gabriel puts up the purse, and walks leisurely into Lady Morden's Dressing-Room.]

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: [following Gabriel] Why, hark you, sirrah!—Come back!—Why, rascal!

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: [calling] St! My Lord! My Lord!

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: [looking back to Harriet, and then recollecting Gabriel] Astonishing effrontery!

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: My Lord!

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: [returning] Oh! Madam, I am distracted.

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: Have patience, but for one quarter of an hour, and I hope to rid you of all your fears, and inflict that punishment, on the author of them, which he dreads most.

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: How, Madam?

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: By exposing him; making him what he delights to make others, a subject of laughter and contempt.

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: Which way, Madam?

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: We may be overheard; step with me into the antichamber, and I'll inform you.

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: [peeping after Lord Morden and Harriet, and then calling] Sir Frederic!—Sir Frederic!

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Well, what's the matter? How camest thou off with his Lordship?

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Off? Ecod, I—I wish you may come off as well.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: I!

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Ees.—Why, mun, there be the bailiffs, below!

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Bailiffs!

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Ees—Sent by the Irish gentleman, lady I mean, a'ter your worship!—Ecod, hur is detarmined to ha' you, safe!

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: The Devil! What's to be done!—Is she with them?

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: No; hur be come back, and is gone into the antichamber, wi' my Lord.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: And has not seen them?

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Likely not.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Here, quick, change clothes with me, and tell them you are Sir Frederic Fashion.

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Me!—Ecod, thank you for that—No, no—I would na' be in your coat, for fifty pound!

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Fool! they durst not detain you.

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: I'll take care they shan't.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: S'death! What's to be done?

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Ecod—Suppose—Suppose I wur to go, and tell the Irish gentleman somebody wanted hur; and so make 'em arrest she?

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Ha! Exquisite fellow! I conceive—Away, send her instantly!

div3.head: SCENE XII. SIR FREDERIC, TWO BAILIFFS.

sp.speaker: Bailiff.
sp.p: Is your name Sir Frederic Fashion, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: No, Sir; but Sir Frederic will be here, directly; if you have any business with him.

sp.speaker: Bailiff.
sp.p: [aside to his companion] Have your handkerchief ready, should he make any noise, for fear of a rescue—This is a very serious affair. [to Sir Frederic] Pray, Sir, what kind of person is Sir Frederic?

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Um—a handsome—agreeable little gentleman, and very young.

sp.speaker: Bailiff.
sp.p: May I ask, Sir, how he is dressed?

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: [aside] Gad! well remember'd.— [to the bailiffs] Dressed, oh! he is dressed for—for the masquerade—Here he comes. [the Bailiffs retire a little upon the watch.]

div3.head: SCENE XIII. SIR FREDERIC, BAILIFFS, HARRIET.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: [to Harriet] Well, Sir Frederic! Ha, ha, ha! How goes your scheme.

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: Oh, ho!—Faidth, and are you so jocular?

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: I have been thinking this is a dangerous business, and would advise you not to give the girl that contract—It may bring you into trouble.

sp.speaker: Bailiff.
sp.p: [aside to his companion] You hear!

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: Oh! Faidth, and she has it safe enough.

sp.speaker: Bailiff.
sp.p: [advances] Sir Frederic Fashion [touches Harriet on the shoulder], you are my prisoner, Sir,—I have a special writ against you.

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! Against me!—Arrah, frind, but you are making a bit of a bull here.

sp.speaker: Bailiff.
sp.p: We know what we are about, Sir; my carriage is below; you shall be treated like a gentleman; but we must beg you to go with us, instantly, and without noise.

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: [alarmed and forgetting the brogue] I tell you, friend, you mistake the person.

div3.head: SCENE XIV. SIR FREDERIC, HARRIET, BAILIFFS, GABRIEL.

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: [goes up to Harriet] Here, Sir Frederic; here be a card, from Colonel Castoff, wi' his compliments.

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: Sirrah! Me!

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: [with pretended astonishment] Ees, to be sure!

sp.speaker: Bailiff.
sp.p: Sir, we must be gone.

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: This is a concerted trick—Here— [as soon as Harriet begins to call, the bailiffs clap the handkerchief over her mouth, and hurry off with her.]

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Did not I do it rarely?

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Do!—I could wonder and worship thee! In half a year, thou would'st make an ass of Machiavel!—Oh that I could but retrieve that cursed contract.

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: I do think I could get it.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Ay!—Nay, I do, almost, begin to believe in miracles! Which way?

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: No matter for that—What will you gi' me?

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Whatever thou canst wish—A hundred guineas—

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: And the place in the Excise?

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Any thing, every thing!—Run, try, fly!—Think, succeed, and I'll make an Emperor of thee!

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Ees—I'll be Emperor of Excise-men.

div3.head: SCENE XVI. SIR FREDERIC, MRS. MODELY, EMILY.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: The shrewdness, and abilities, of this fellow are amazing!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Modely.
sp.p: [entering] Yes, my sweet little Emily, the greatest beauty in London would be envied, had she made such a conquest.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Ah!—▪You say so.—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Modely.
sp.p: Say! Why, to-morrow morning, the whole town will be in a flame!

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Well, that will be pure!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Modely.
sp.p: Oh! Sir Frederic—

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: [runs to Emily] My life! My soul! My transport!

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: [to Mrs. Modely] What sweet words!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Modely.
sp.p: You are very much obliged to me, I assure you.—I have been speaking to my sweet, dear, little Emily, here, in your behalf.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Then, Madam, I am, inexpressibly, obliged to you!

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Yes, Mrs. Modely is very much your friend, and very much my friend—A'n't you, Mrs. Modely?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Modely.
sp.p: Yes, my little dear; I am, indeed, very much your friend: and, if I had not the best opinion in the world of Sir Frederic, would not have spoken as I have.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Well, Sir Frederic, have you ordered the chaise and four?

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: [pretending to be afraid Mrs. Modely should overhear]. Yes!—Hush!

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Nay, you may say any thing before Mrs. Modely. I have told her all; for, you know, she is my friend.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Modely.
sp.p: Yes, yes, Sir Frederic; be assured, I will not betray any secret, the keeping of which will make my dear Emily so happy!

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Yes, we shall be so happy!—You know, Sir Frederic, you swear to marry me.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Solemnly! [all through the scene he looks anxiously round, at intervals, fearful of being surprised.]

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Well, but, swear it again; now, before Mrs. Modely.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: By all the saints!

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Saints! Pshaw! You should swear by—by my bright eyes, that dim the stars.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Oh! By those bright eyes, that dim the blazing Sun.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: And—and, my beauties, that eclipse the blushing Moon!

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Ay, by those, and all your burning charms, I swear.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: To marry me, the moment we come to Scotland?

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: The moment we come to Scotland.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: And, if we are pursued—

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: To fight for you! Die for you!

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Oh! That will be delightful!—

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: [aside] The Devil it will!

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Come, let us set off!—My bandbox is ready!

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: That is impossible, my angel!

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Impossible?

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: I have not ordered the chaise, till ten o'clock.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Oh dear! What, two whole hours longer!

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: They are two ages, I grant— [looking round] Forgive my fears, my deares Emily; but, tho' the pleasure of your company is the most precious thing on earth—a—a—yet—

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: What, you want me gone?

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Rather than you should think so unkindly, I will run the hazard of being surprised, and eternally separated from you.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Will you! I am sure you don't love me then—However, I'll go.—You will be sure to be ready, the moment the clock strikes ten.

div3.head: SCENE XVII. SIR FREDERIC, MRS. MODELY.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Time is precious—Here have been such plots, against me!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Modely.
sp.p: Plots!

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Oh! I have escaped Scylla and Charybdis! But wind and tide are, now, both with me—Lady Morden is to meet me, here, in half an hour. Thro' that door is her chamber.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Modely.
sp.p: Oh, you vile creature!

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: What prude, to-morrow, will dare pretend that woman, and education, are a match for man, and nature?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Modely.
sp.p: And so you will persist in your wickedness, in spite of my persuasions!

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Lady Morden has, still, all the rhodomontade of love, in her brain—Thinks of nothing but cooing-constancy, and eternal raptures!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Modely.
sp.p: Simple woman!

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Except, indeed, tormenting her husband; which seems to give the sin a double sweetness.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Modely.
sp.p: Or she would be no wife!

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: So, as soon as I am gone off with Emily, I will have a consolatory epistle delivered to her.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Modely.
sp.p: Compassionate toad!

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Here it is, ready written; and, if I don't flatter myself, a master-piece.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Modely.
sp.p: Let me see! Let me see!

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: No, you shall hear. [reads] Dear Madam, Tho' you are an angel, if there are other angels, am I to blame?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Modely.
sp.p: Certainly not.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: [reads] If man is naturally inconstant, and if I am a man—am I to blame?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Modely.
sp.p: Certainly not.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: [reads] If nature has made variety the highest enjoyment—am I to blame?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Modely.
sp.p: Certainly not.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: [reads] If, since happiness is the pursuit of us all, I am happy as often as I can—am I to blame?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Modely.
sp.p: Certainly not.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: [reads] Farewell, Madam; circumstances, as you will find, force me, thus suddenly, from your arms, in which, I own, I found heaven centered: but, if you should call me cruel, perjured, and ungrateful, because I act naturally, and therefore rationally—am I to blame?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Modely.
sp.p: Certainly not!—Well, as I live, this is a master-stroke! Perfectly as I thought I knew you, you have astonished me!

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Yes; 'tis the true Socratic mode—But, now, my dear Mrs. Modely, go you to Emily, prevent her disturbing us, and keep her in readiness.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Modely.
sp.p: Well! remember, every thing is at stake, and be yourself.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Fear me not; that prescience, which, they say, is the forerunner of all great events, gives me a happy assurance of success: a confidence, that makes success certain.

sp.speaker: General Burland.
sp.p: I Cannot keep from this house!—There is a foreboding of mischief, which haunts, and perturbs, my imagination!—And, I fear, with reason!—The malignant joy, the smothered exult, the obscure, ironical, satire, which ran through the discourse of that Sir Frederic, were not without a meaning.—I wish I had not consented to let Emily stay—He sneered, I remember, at the moment: nay, it seemed the sneer of triumph!—I wish she were safe, at my own house.—Poor Lady Morden!—And, is it possible?—Such rectitude of heart!—Such purity of sentiment!—I wish Emily were at home—Should my child, my darling fall, I were a wretch indeed!

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: [wildly] I am miserable! distracted! racked!—The thunderbolt has struck before I heard it!—Oh that its exterminating power had been final! But it has maimed, and deformed, and left a full feeling of wretchedness!

sp.speaker: Gen. Burland.
sp.p: How now, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: General!—I am a wretch!—An irretrievable, eternal, wretch!

sp.speaker: Gen. Burland.
sp.p: What, and are you come to a sense of this, now it is too late?

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: There's the misery!—The curse is accomplished, and hope is fled!

sp.speaker: Gen. Burland.
sp.p: Why, ay! Such is the infatuation of folly, and vice, they will not believe vengeance has an arm, till its fatal gripe is felt!

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: I cannot support these tortures!—Oh that it were possible!—

sp.speaker: Gen. Burland.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: To reclaim Lady Morden.

sp.speaker: Gen. Burland.
sp.p: What then? Another month and Sir Frederic Fashion, or any other libertine of fashion, might take her.

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: Never!—Never!—Were her affections once again mine, the stroke of death, only, should separate us!

sp.speaker: Gen. Burland.
sp.p: [with deep compassion] Well, my Lord, if you are, at last, convinced of the immensity of your loss—I pity you!

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: Oh, would you could relieve!

sp.speaker: Gen. Burland.
sp.p: Would I could!—But, you were a witness how ineffectual my endeavours were. However, walk with me, into the antichamber, and let us consult what is best to be done.—Her principles, I fear, are shaken; the only rock on which virtue can stand secure.

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p:
Sapped, destroyed!—She avows her intents! Unblushingly avows them! And, recapitulating my errors, my crimes, dares me to complain of, or notice, hers! Scorns and contemns me, and justly too, that such a thing as I
should pretend to repeat, or respect, the word virtue!

sp.speaker: Gen. Burland.
sp.p: It is what every husband, every father of a family, must expect! His smallest foibles will stand as precedents for a swarm of follies; and, if he has any vices, they will propagate a hideous brood, that shall extirpate his name from the earth, or overwhelm it with obloquy!

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: [peeping after Lord Morden, and the General] Come, mun!—Your worship, come!

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Are they gone?

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Ees.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Well, what hast thou done?—Where is Harriet?

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Oh, I ha' her safe.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Thou!

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Ees, mun—For, when the Bailiffs found out a wur a woman, they wur parfitly ravenous!

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: And let her go?

sp.speaker: Gabriel
sp.p: Ees.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: S'death!

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: But, I secured her.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Secured! Impossible! How?

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Nay, never do you mind how—I tell'ee, I ha' her safe.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: But where are the Bailiffs?

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: In this house.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: The devil they are!

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Ees, they be—waiting for your worship.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Death and destruction!

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: But what o'that? I a'got the contract, mun.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Hast thou?

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Ees, here it is.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Precious fellow! I could worship thee!—Give it me.

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: [putting his hand behind him.] Nay, hold there!—I wunna do that.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Won't!

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: No—I wunna.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Pshaw! Make no words, but deliver it—and, here—here is—

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Nay, put up your paper, for I wunna part wi' mine.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: S'death, fellow!

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Nay, be mild tempered—stand where you be; for an you stir another step, I'll call the Bailiffs.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: [aside] Cunning scoundrel!—He has me in his power, and time presses.—Well, Gabriel, be faithful, and, depend on't, I'll make thee a clever fellow.

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Why, ecod, I think I am like a Monmouth-street coat—ready made.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Thou rememberest the instructions I gave thee?

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Parfitly.

sp.speaker: Sir. Frederic.
sp.p: The chaise is to wait, at the corner of the street.

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Ees.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Thou art to convey Emily's bandbox away, privately; and, if any questions are asked, to say it is Lady Morden's.

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Ees.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Hast thou taken care of the letter, I gave thee?

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Care! Ees, ees; I a' ta'en good care on't.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Observe, thou art to deliver, it to Lady Morden, half an hour after we are departed.

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Half an hour before you are departed.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Zounds! No, half an hour after, man.

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Oh! Ees, ees; half an hour after.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Now begone.

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: But—but, how will your worship get by the Bailiffs?

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: S'death, that's true!—Is there no disguise?

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Why—ees—there be a long greatcoat i'th' hall.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Ay, true!—Bring it me.

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Nay, nay—I'll put it on first, and let 'em see me—so, then, when they see you, they'll think it be I—

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Excellent! Where are Lord Morden, and the General?

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: I'th' t'other chamber.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Unlucky! I wish they were any where else.

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Oh!—an that be all, I'll soon make 'em budge.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Nay!—Lord, you're so quisitive!—I tell you, I'll do't—I'll saunter thro' this door, lock it, and send 'em packing thro' t'other.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Thou art the prince of plotters—Away, be vigilant.

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Oh! never do you fear me!

div3.head: SCENE IV. SIR FREDERIC, LADY MORDEN.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: This fellow would outwit a whole conclave of Cardinals!

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: Well, Sir Frederic! here I am, you see; punctual to my promise.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: [with vast insinuation, seeming sincerity, and humble rapture, all through the scene.] Oh, Madam, how can I repay this bounty!—this condescension!—Never!—My life were a poor sacrifice, to such sweetness and such charms!

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: Sir Frederic, this is a trying, a decisive moment! I am going to be either the most happy or the most wretched of women! You tell me, it is your wish, your resolution, to be no longer that general lover, that man of the world, you have, hitherto, been thought.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Say not, dear Lady, it is either my wish or resolution! Heaven can testify, I have not the power to be any thing, but what it shall please you to make me!

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: I have owned to you that, the levity I have lately affected is not natural to me▪ that my heart sighs for an acquaintance, a mate▪ that, like itself, is subject to all the sweet emotions of sensibility!—Yes, it was the first wish of my soul to find this correspondent heart! A heart beating with the same ardour, vibrating to the same sensations, panting for the same pleasures, shrinking from the same pangs; pliant, yet firm; gentle, yet aspiring; passionate, yet pure!—Such I once thought Lord Morden's—Should I, a second time, be deceived!

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: I am poor in proofs of sincerity! I have none to offer!—My former errors are present punishments! To deny or even palliate them would imply intentional deceit; and this is a moment in which I would wish for men and gods to be witnesses of my truth!—I have had, I own, most libertine opinions of your gentle sex; but these I, now, solemnly renounce!—Had I, before, met with a Lady Morden, I should, before, have made this renunciation!—But, perhaps, the women it has been my misfortune to know deserved, in part, the light esteem in which I held them.—Never, till now, did I find one who could mutually inspire such passion and respect! Such agitated, burning, hopes! Such excruciating fears, or thoughts so sanctified, as those I, this moment, feel!

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: Yet, Sir Frederic, I cannot help observing your conversation, in society, seems still tinged with the impurity of your former libertine principles.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: I own, Lady Morden, with confusion own, I have not hitherto had the courage, or, perhaps, I have wanted strength to stem the torrent: but, aided by you, I feel, I dare promise any thing!

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: I confess, Sir Frederic, the mind finds some difficulty in rooting out fears, planted in it by reiterated accusations. The stories the world tells of you are dreadful! And, yet, there is such heartfelt conviction attends your present words that, to me, it is impossible to listen and retain a doubt.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p:
This generous confidence transports me, fills me with gratitude, and inspires
rapturous hope! [clasps her round the waist.] Oh, gently suffer me to conduct you, where love lies, in panting, breathless, ecstasy—

div3.head: SCENE V.
div3.stage: To them GABRIEL, abruptly, in a Great-coat, stands fixed, staring.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: [sternly] How now!

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: [deliberately] Belike—You dunna want company?

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: No, Sir.

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: I thought as much—

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: [laying hold of him] Begone, instantly!

sp.speaker: Gabriel
sp.p: Nay! Hands off! [throws him from him] I shan't stir, till I have delivered my message.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: What message? What have you to say?

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: [aloud] Why the chaise and four be come.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: [still louder] The bandbox ready.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Infernal booby!

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Miss Emily waiting.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: [violently] Begone, I say.

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Gone!—Nay, sartinly, you would no' ha' I run away wi' her.

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: [with contempt] Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Lady Morden!

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p:
Ha, ha, ha!—Why, surely, you! The never failing victor! The fertile-brained Sir Frederic Fashion! who knows not defeat, and who never, yet, was at a loss for stratagems!
Though you are taken somewhat unawares, you cannot want invention!

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: You'll pardon me, Madam, if I want understanding to comprehend your meaning.

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: Indeed!—Well, if you are so very dull of apprehension—am I to blame?

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Madam!

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: Oh!—Do you recollect—this letter?

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: How!—Faithless fiend! [goes to assault Gabriel, who throws back his great-coat and appears dressed as a gentleman.]

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Keep off, or dread the chastisement I am prompted, instantaneously, to inflict!

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Chastisement!—What is this?—Who are you?

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: A man!—You are—

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: For heaven's sake, brother!—

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Brother!

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Gabriel Wilmot; whose head is so full of the nonsense of friendship, honour, and honesty!

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: I'll be revenged, however.

div3.head: SCENE VI.
div3.stage: To them LORD MORDEN and GENERAL

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: Turn, wretch, and receive your punishment from this arm! [Sir Frederic turns on Lord Morden.]

sp.speaker: Gen. Burland.
sp.p: [beating down their swords] Oh, for shame!—Look to the Lady—

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: Oh, General!—Oh, my Lord! [runs to Lord Morden and falls on his neck.]

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: My life! My ecstasy! My saviour!

div3.head: SCENE VII.
div3.stage: To them MRS. MODELY and EMILY.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Modely.
sp.p: Bless me, what uproar—Hey day!— [aside] So, so! Here is a very pretty denouement to our plot, indeed!— [aloud] I see, good folks, you are all embroiled here; and, as it is a very disagreeable thing to be present at family disputes, I'll— [is going; the General plants himself against the door]

sp.speaker: Gen. Burland.
sp.p: Pray, Madam, stay, and receive the compliments of the company—Mine, and your friend Emily's, in particular.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Modely.
sp.p: Oh, with pleasure!

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: Mr. Wilmot! My best brother!—Though you have, in part, acquainted me with what is past, yet, it is so sudden—And you! my dearest Lady! To find you still the same is joy unspeakable!

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: The task of making you suppose I had effectually become what I seemed, was, indeed, most painful; but the loss of your affection were not pain! 'Twere horror!—I told you my passion was too permanent to be shaken—Ah! how could you imagine I meant another? Or think it possible I ever could forget that chaste, that ardent, that eternal, love, I have so repeatedly vowed?

sp.speaker: Lord Morden.
sp.p: Oh for words!—I am all love! gratitude! rapture! and amazement!

sp.speaker: Gen. Burland.
sp.p: And so is Sir Frederic, apparently—Nay, even you, Madam, seem a little surprised.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Modely.
sp.p: Me! Oh dear, no.

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: [to Sir Frederic] Dear Sir, though you are a deep and excellent plotter, if there have been counterplots—am I to blame? [curtsies.]

sp.speaker: Mrs. Modely.
sp.p: [with affected candour] Certainly not.

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: If man is sometimes vain, presumptuous, and unprincipled, and if you are a man—am I to blame?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Modely.
sp.p: Certainly not.

sp.speaker: Mr. Wilmot.
sp.p: If I assumed a mean disguise, that I might aid a sister, to detect, and expose, the mean machinations of Seduction—am I to blame?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Modely.
sp.p: Certainly not.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: If, following the advice of this dear Lady [to Lady Morden] simplicity has made cunning outwit itself—am I to blame? [curtsying first to Sir Frederic, and then to Mrs. Modely.]

sp.speaker: Gen. Burland.
sp.p: [with vast pleasure] Certainly not.

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: If, since happiness is the pursuit of us all, I wish to be as happy as possible— [most affectionately taking Lord Morden's hand] am I to blame?

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Certainly not.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: [with affected ease] Certainly not—So, the catechism being ended, the scholars may depart.

sp.speaker: Mr. Wilmot.
sp.p: Certainly not.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Mr. Wilmot.
sp.p: You forget the bailiffs.

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: Besides, Sir Frederic, before you go, you must give me leave to introduce you to—

div3.head: SCENE THE LAST.
div3.stage: To them HARRIET in woman's clothes presented by Lady Morden.

sp.p: —This Lady.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Harriet!

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: Yes, Sir—that Harriet, whom, hearing she had happiness in view, and proportioning your ideal triumph to the weight of misery you might entail, you raised heaven and earth to bring to wretchedness, and ruin.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Modely.
sp.p: Upon my honour, you—you are a sad man, Sir Frederic!—A very sad man!
sp.stage: [The company by their looks shew they understand Mrs. Modely's real character.]

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: But your vanity is humbled—you, now, stand detected; and, instead of envied, you will be sneered at by the depraved, pitied by the good, and, henceforth, avoided by the credulous young creatures you, so manfully, have delighted to involve in guilt, and destruction!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Modely.
sp.p: A very dangerous man, indeed, Sir Frederic!

sp.speaker: General.
sp.p: [ironically] Ay! beware of him, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Modely.
sp.p: Oh! I—I will!

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, the finger of scorn points where it ought: you are exposed, and my resentment is appeased.

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Then, Madam—the—the contract—

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p:
There it is, Sir. [returns it] I never meant to make any other use of it than what has
been better effected, by different means. [curtsying to Lady Morden and Mr. Wilmot.]

sp.speaker: Sir Frederic.
sp.p: Madam!—

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: No thanks, Sir.

sp.speaker: Gen. Burland.
sp.p: No; they would sit a little awkwardly.

sp.speaker: Lady Morden.
sp.p: And now, Sir Frederic, if, after this lesson, you should still retain your former principles, and practices, and, hereafter, receive a still severer punishment, I hope you will acknowledge—we are not to blame.

lg.l: IN former times—'tis long ago, I own—
Man, seated on the haughty husband's throne,
The wife by such absurd restraints enclos'd,
Not one gallant had she—as he suppos'd:
But, modest, meek, his jealous doubts appeas'd,
And sooth'd her lord and master—when she pleas'd.
Then, women led such exemplary lives,
Daughters, almost, as humble were—a—as wives!
"A savage Salick law the men maintain'd;
"O monstrous! We were slaves! and husband's reign'd."—
Strange were these customs, obsolete; but we
Consolidate our customs—and, you see,
Such wise designs no opposition find:
A fair free trade is good for all mankind.
The lib'ral spirit of our lib'ral beauties
Has quite annull d prohibitory duties.
The Cicisbeo, and the chere amie,
On the broad base of reciprocity,
Are exports now, and imports, duty free.
As for this Lady Morden's motley merit,
With her half-ancient, her half-modern spirit,
You'll imitate the part you most approve;
Her modish licence, or her maukish love!
Of that no more—The subject of my speech,
The doctrine I came, purposely, to teach,
(Nay, look not low'ring, man of mighty sense)
Is rival woman's super-eminence—*
"Yes, we have proofs where wit, where taste combin'
"To deck, with blended charms, the female mind.
"Say, shall not we, with conscious pride, proclaim
"A female critic rais'd—ev'n Shakespear's Fame!
"Yes, lordly man—look surly if you please,
"But women beat you out and out, with ease!
"In tales of fancy, tenderness, distress,
"If you dare doubt us—study The Recess.
"And oft let soft Cecilia win your praise;
"While Reason guides the clue, in Fancy's maze.
"In tragedy our triumph all attest;
"Your tears the genuine proof who acts the best—
"In comedy—But hold—I dread to say
"How much, of late, ev'n there, you've lost the day."
No, I'll not humble your proud sex so far,
Till you no more remember—SUCH THINGS ARE.
Gladly our author owns, all this is true;
Nor thinks he's robb'd, when others have their due:
Yet, owning, hopes you've kindly heard his cause;
Hopes to participate your just applause.
And, should your hands some grateful wreath combine,
And should that wreath his anxious brow entwine,
The prize most precious mem'ry holds in store,

It there shall bloom—'till mem'ry is no more!
* The verses, between inverted commas, were requested from, and written by, a gentleman whose literary abilities are great, and well known; and the following were, consequently, omitted.
Is rival woman's super-eminence
In wit, as well as beauty! Proofs I could
But will not cite, to make th' assertion good.
Why should I speak, what's known to Fame and you,
Young André's woes; the wrongs of old Peru?
Why the Belle's Stratagem, or Percy name;
Or sweet Cecilia's never ending fame?
Our comic, or our tragic, triumphs quote;
Or tell how Siddons acted, Burney wrote?
No, I'll not humble, &c.
